article.title: Single photoionization of the Zn II ion in the photon energy range 17.5 to 90.0 eV: experiment and theory

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the open circles (magenta) in Figure 1 (a) and (b) represent?
choices: Theoretical DARC PI cross section calculations.
Absolute PI cross section measurements.
ALS experimental data for the single photoionization cross section of Zn+.
Thresholds for Zn2+(3d10 1So) and Zn2+(3d94s 1D2).

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 1 (a), what is the significance of the blue, red, and green lines, respectively?
choices: They represent the DARC PI calculations for the ground state, the two metastable states, and the sum of all contributions.
They represent the DARC PI calculations for the ground state, the two metastable states, and the experimental data.
They represent the ALS measurements, the DARC PI calculations for the ground state, and the average of the metastable state contributions.
They represent the ALS measurements, the DARC PI calculations for the ground state, and the combined ground and metastable contributions.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of Figure 1 (b) compared to Figure 1 (a)?
choices: To compare the ALS measurements and the DARC PI calculations with and without the correction factor fe.
To illustrate the agreement between the DARC PI calculations and the ALS measurements when considering an appropriate mixture of ground and metastable states.
To demonstrate the effect of convoluting the DARC results with a Gaussian having a profile width of 17 meV.
To highlight the contribution of the metastable states to the overall photoionization cross section.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be observed in the spectrum of Figure 1 below the ionization threshold (marked by the vertical line)?
choices: The cross section drops to zero, indicating no photoionization below the threshold.
The cross section exhibits sharp resonance features, suggesting autoionizing states below the threshold.
The cross section exhibits a non-zero value, potentially due to higher-order radiation or metastable contamination.
The cross section fluctuates significantly, indicating a high degree of uncertainty in the measurements.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key difference between panels (a) and (b) in Figure 2?
choices: Panel (a) shows the ALS data, while panel (b) shows the DARC calculations.
Panel (a) shows the present ALS measurements, while panel (b) shows the earlier findings of Peart et al. (1987).
Panel (a) displays the entire energy range, while panel (b) focuses on a restricted region.
Panel (a) uses a linear scale for the cross section, while panel (b) uses a logarithmic scale.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the vertical lines in Figure 2 indicate?
choices: The positions of the resonant energies of identified Rydberg series.
The limits of the energy range investigated in the respective panels.
The thresholds for the different Zn2+ core states.
The positions of the peaks reported by Peart et al. (1987).

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be observed about the peaks reported by Peart et al. (1987) in Figure 2(b) compared to the present ALS measurements and the DARC calculations?
choices: They are in excellent agreement with both the ALS measurements and the DARC calculations.
They are shifted toward higher energies, or shorter wavelengths.
They exhibit much narrower widths compared to the ALS measurements.
They exhibit a significantly lower signal-to-noise ratio.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn from the presence of the downward pointing solid triangles (red) in Figure 2?
choices: They indicate the presence of higher-order photons in the photon beam.
They identify a Zn+(3d94s np), n â‰¥ 6, Rydberg resonance series.
They mark the positions of overlapping resonance peaks.
They represent the estimated resonance positions based on the DARC calculations.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the effective quantum number v in analyzing resonance series?
choices: It is directly proportional to the energy of the resonance.
It is inversely proportional to the resonance width.
It helps to identify the final state of the Zn2+ ion after photoionization.
It helps to differentiate between resonances originating from different initial states.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded about the resonance line widths based on the data presented in Figure 4?
choices: The widths are too large to be accurately determined with the present experimental resolution.
The widths generally decrease with increasing effective quantum number.
The widths show no clear dependence on the effective quantum number.
The widths are consistently smaller for J=3/2 odd symmetry compared to J=1/2 odd symmetry.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the open triangles (red) and open circles (blue) represent in Figure 4?
choices: Theoretical values and experimental values, respectively, for the resonance line widths.
Resonance line widths for J=1/2 odd symmetry and J=3/2 odd symmetry, respectively.
Resonance line widths for the ground state and the metastable state, respectively.
Resonance line widths for the ALS measurements and the DARC calculations, respectively.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main limitation in extracting accurate resonance line widths from the ALS data in this experiment?
choices: The presence of overlapping resonance peaks.
The limited energy range investigated in the experiment.
The low signal-to-noise ratio of the ALS measurements.
The limited photon energy resolution of 17 meV FWHM.
